header.title: Ageism in The Design Industry: Where Are All the Older Creative Professionals?
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Age discrimination is sadly very pervasive in the design and creative industries. Professionals in the prime of their careers and at the peak of their abilities are being sidelined and forced out of positions in design and creative departments in companies, agencies and corporations at an astounding rate. Why is this happening? How will it affect your career? What can you do about it? . . This video is targeted to my channel's audience of entrepreneurs, designers, creative professionals and anyone interested in brand strategy, business planning, design, trend, marketing and communications.. . Philip VanDusen is the founder of Verhaal Brand Design, a brand strategy and design agency in the New York City metro area. He is an accomplished creative executive and expert in brand strategy, graphic design, marketing and creative management. Philip gives design, branding, marketing, career and business advice to creative professionals, entrepreneurs and companies on how to build successful brands for themselves or for the clients they serve.. . commentThread.commentText: I find being open, flexible and not so worried about hierarchy works well. Some senior people in the design industry guard a sense of importance. This old-school stiff authoritative figure just makes everyone feel uncomfortable especially if your young and not so bothered about hierarchy anymore. Dropping the ego and focusing on being open, encouraging and positivity will help allot. I'm 46 and love working with young designers, I'm freelance and not worried about my position I just enjoy great ideas and being around good people.

replies.commentText: Hey Stephen, Great perspective. Undoubtedly some guard their level of seniority -mainly because unfortunately hierarchy is linked with salary. While the "flat org" is where many companies are going there still needs to be a celebration and utilization of the accumulated experience older contributors bring to the table...and unfortunately that perspective is getting more rare in the industry.

commentThread.commentText: As I sometimes say, we were "beta test millenials" - the GenX people who were the early adopters of creative tech and social media.  We'll have a more fundamental understanding of these things, and will take them less for granted because we can remember a time before.

replies.commentText: VJ, agree. The perspective of "what it was like before" helps to assign value - but that need (or even appreciation) is fading it seems.

commentThread.commentText: Is 59 too old to continue in web design and Elearning?

replies.commentText: Chris - not if you do it as an independent. Landing a gig with a co. or a agency at 59 if you are just starting a new line of work will be tough.

commentThread.commentText: Thank you for this. I was particularly happy when you said don't let your age stop you and that it is never too late. I know you were talking to more like the '30s or '40s, but this 60-year-old is taking it to heart and going full steam ahead. Thank you again for your content, it has been very helpful.

replies.commentText: Hey Mary! 60 is the new 40...;-)

commentThread.commentText: That is so funny Picasso was very creative when he was very old - this focus on young fools only is actually what creates shallow brands and very cheap tricks - I would mix teams with old brand veterans and young tough cats

replies.commentText: Hey STUDIO B, Thanks for watching and taking the time to comment. I appreciate your sharing your POV.

commentThread.commentText: The same with technology... There was an article where they were asking why there wasn't many women in the friend. One of the reasons was that the youngers had not an old role models in the field.

replies.commentText: Kola, That's true and it is a self-perpetuating scenario. It starts with sexist or ageist or racist hiring practices and morphs into a long-term deficit in diversity in the workplace.

commentThread.commentText: YES! and sexist as well groovy middle aged men in black tees will be ranked higher than a 50 something female sad and true

replies.commentText: Both of the global agencies I was an ECD at had female Presidents and female Managing Directors. I'm not saying you're wrong, but my personal experience has seen it to be more balanced in upper management anyway.

commentThread.commentText: Ageism is so real! I went through a phase of applying to full time jobs, and I'm being interviewed by 30 year olds and the whole team is under 35. 35 is not old. Because of this, and many other observations, I was confirmed the corporate world is not for me. But, I didn't let it bother me, and others over 40 shouldn't be concerned either. There are other sectors to design for with an older demographic. And, there are 4 decades (people in their 40s, 50s, 60s and even 70s) of business people who have different focuses than the youth working at Google, Facebook, Amazon, etc... and they need design too. If you are good and stay current, there is a tribe for you who needs your design. Make a client base who is your age and older and you will not feel the immature prejudice o f ageism. I realize my comments apply more to people who are running their own business, and I guess that is where most older designer go.

replies.commentText: Very true. Dude we have a LOT of perspectives in common. Be sure to connect with me on LinkedIn.

commentThread.commentText: I 37... And I guess that is not so old. Nut I feel like the older you ate the more experience you have... Age comes value.

replies.commentText: Thanks jarmelo2006! Always good to see you here my friend. No, 37 is not that old - and experience does count for a lot in the design field, even though it can be ageist. There are a lot of companies, agencies and clients who value deeper experience in the field to help them with their challenges.

commentThread.commentText: This is something I've been thinking more about this past year.  It's more motivation to get back to updating my website and creating more personal projects. Thank you, Phillip!

replies.commentText: Sean, the sooner the better my friend!

commentThread.commentText: Shout out from South Africa! I love your videos, thanks for the masses of inspiration and knowledge you bring to the table. I am 28 and starting my Creative Director and Share Holder career in about 4 days! Super excited but also nervous, but after watching this video I feel I have made the right decision and going on the right path. I will be watching A LOT of your videos in the coming months. Keep up the amazing work!

replies.commentText: Thanks Marc, I'm glad you are digging my stuff and I'm excited to hear about your career journey as it develops. Be sure to come back to the comments and update me on your progress. I read every one - and respond to 99.9%  of them!

commentThread.commentText: This was important information to know...!! Thanks alot !!

replies.commentText: Hey Dashia- great to see you!

commentThread.commentText: Philip, I love your videos and mailing! Keep bringing them! Thanks a lot for sharing! That's a topic ( ageism) I have been thinking a lot! I work exclusively as freelancer since 2013 and it seems to be almost the only way to keep surviving in the creative industry (and for book design, it really seems to be the only way)

replies.commentText:
renatavidaldesign, You're very welcome. Glad to have you on my list!
Be sure to check out the other videos in my catalog. There's tons of great stuff there!

commentThread.commentText: Younger people cost less, generally.

replies.commentText: Yeah, there's that...didn't I mention that? If I didn't that was a huge miss on my part...

commentThread.commentText: I totally agree with your comments. I used to work in an ad agency with a lot of creative directors. Sadly, they are all gone and now hen I look at their online portfolio, I see a lot of trendy & mostly with very weak design. Other important topic on this subject: The younger designer are getting payed way less. So the companies save money.

replies.commentText: Kani- you are right on all counts!

commentThread.commentText: Why does ageism exist? Because employers can get away with paying junior wages. I got into digital design 30 years ago then transferred into motion graphics then video production. I've never been more skilled and accomplished in my life. However, If I worked for someone else I'd get less than half of what I'm worth, not enough to pay bills. I agree, the answer is to build your own brand AND work with someone who excels in marketing before you go it alone. Design is very accessible now, the market is saturated and there are too many players. Employers know this too and prey of it.

replies.commentText: Matt - all so true. Design and the creative professions have been massively commoditized. The effects on the global economy and the availability of designers around the world to who $30 is a months wages. IMHO, the only solution is to offer a higher level of thinking, strategy and consulting advice to take you above the masses. Your advice to partner with someone good at marketing before you strike out on your own is a great one!

@Philip VanDusen what really struck me about your video is that the design profession has a shelf life. I hated hearing that but it's so true. I'm in the prime of my career but f-cked trying to find a job - not that I really want to work for someone else. I've taught at a few film and tv schools (motion graphics, DSLRs, editing etc.) I honestly felt like telling the students that this might become a hobby for them not a profession. I don't think I'm being pessimistic about the design industry situation, just realistic. I'm pretty sure the music industry has gone down the same path as well. Many of the available jobs out there specify design skills as a subset of another profession ie. wanted: Journalist, must know motion graphics and editing, or wanted: Marketer, must know video skills, HTML5 coder, must know photoshop and editing... the design landscape has shifted dramatically. Here's another issue that I'd like to bring up... to get ahead as a young kid in school, you have to be gifted academically, not creatively. There's not as many options for a creative career nowadays. I feel for young creatives.

@Matt Urmenyhazi Yes it does have a shelf life, and it IS hard to hear - and even harder to have manifest itself in your life - as you and thousands of others are finding out everyday. You comment about the hybrid-position phenomenon is really on point. I've been thinking about that a lot, too. That's why I'm out here trying to teach creative pros to branch out - learn to write, produce content, learn marketing, learn strategy. If anywhere, that is where the career insurance is.

commentThread.commentText:
Hi Phlip , I want your suggestions and oppinion , I'm a web designer , i've been work on 99design contest for about 8 years now , here is my portfolio in 99designs https://99designs.com/profiles/yani99design , but somehow i still struggle to win the contest. and i want to get steady clients with a good payment for my designs , what should i do to find the clients? i wanted to have my own website but i cant write coding and cant affort yet to hire someone to coding. i hope to hear from you soon 
Thanks
yani

replies.commentText: Yani- I don't really recommend sites like UpWork, 99 Designs etc. They are a race to the bottom - favor the client and devalue the designer - and I completely am against spec work - which is what these sites promote. I've done a bunch of videos on how to find clients. Look through my past videos in my channel catalog and you'l find some great ideas.
@Philip VanDusen thank you for the replay Philip , what do you hink of my designs work?

commentThread.commentText: I'll say it again, designers need to stand together against capitalism. This is not a joke, or anything to take lightly. We will be destroyed by this system unless we unite against it

replies.commentText: Fight the power Woke.

commentThread.commentText: I started working at the office, but then moved to freelancing when I was 22. I never regretted this decision. No one even knows my age, and I never even seen my clients. I earn approximately the same amount of money. The drawback I have to constantly learn something new to stay relevant. I am more flexible, and can go to the gym when I want. After 35, the issue of age brings up on interviews. I'm not sure there's anything we can do about it. Everybody wants fresh new minds. My girlfriend works as a recruiter for manual labor workers, and they take workers only up to 45. That's the upper limit. In CG, they expect you to be a solid professional by th e age of 30-35.

replies.commentText: MIke - good move. I wish I'd done it sooner TBH.
@Philip VanDusen but you've got a lot of experience working in a team, isn't it? Freelance is a bit limiting in that sense.

@Mike Yeah, I've built a huge network over my 30 year career in agencies and corporate which I leverage now in my business. And yes I worked in and managed large teams most my live. Having a solo consultancy is much lonelier, but I work with partners I bring in for projects - so I have co-workers in a way - its not all solo.

@Philip VanDusen What's more important for an artist from your perspective: to grow as an artist, i.e reach for the sky (working on skills), or to build independency as an artist and IP owner, and attaining some kind of a stable income from that independency?

@Mike Refine your skills and get as good as you can at your craft. Establishing independence won't help if you aren't as good as what you do as you can be. Its a constant life-long process - honing your skills, but if I had to prioritize - skills come first.
@Philip VanDusen thank you so much. A very thoughtful reflection.

commentThread.commentText: This was a powerful message and I believe we all can benefit from this. The take away is young designers need guidance and older designers contextually should be building brands not just freelancing. By staying 20 steps ahead not 10 and creating content along with amazing portfolios based off our experience will allow for timeless work that can not be defined by your age

replies.commentText: ...and acts as a safety net when the older designer eventually is side-lined. Because it will happen....and every design thinks they are different.

commentThread.commentText: Without questions. Age discrimination is real in the world of graphic design and marketing. I'm very methodical and critical in my approach of creating logos or corporate branding. To me, that's very important when it comes to designing something that will meet ALL requirements of the purpose in which it was designed and created for.

replies.commentText: Hey Rodney! Sounds like you are doing all the right things. Thanks so much for checking out my video! I appreciate you taking the time to leave a comment. Keep tuning in!

commentThread.commentText: Nice article Phil'. Here in indonesia, clients (my clients) have recently gone through a process of figuring out that the quality of (youngsters in-house) work they now get is... well,.. poor and limited, to say the least. This has led to a 'swing around', literally a rebound effect that has been a boost to our agency. However, the knack, and always will be, is to do great work.. whatever your age.

replies.commentText: Thanks Brendan! Glad to hear your clients are waking up.

commentThread.commentText: Here, here! Was a graphic designer for over 20 years. Got out of it 6 yrs ago. WHY? Too many ppl kept telling me they didn't need my experience as they could get whatever they wanted for FREE online. Getting back into it now though, really missed the profession.

replies.commentText: David, well, yes and no. I actually give a lot of that away free online myself - but lots of people don't have the time or energy to do it themselves...that's where we come in!
Philip VanDusen yes I guess that's one way of looking at it. Thx!

replies.commentText: Evan, that is why I do what I do here on my channel. I want to prepare creative pro's to own their future. What you are seeing is a harsh reality few designers consider until it hits them in the face.

I am new graphic designer.iam working logo design in freelancer.com...i think u have lot of experience about that, so I want logo brand design concept idea pdf book name .there I gate lot of idea about design concept......I hope u help me ...thank u

commentThread.commentText: Thank you for this video. Age discrimination in creative and tech industries are a real problem in today's culture. As the adage would say "Old dogs can learn new tricks."

replies.commentText: Malik - and more importantly - they already know all the old tricks, which the young pups do not - and who fall victim to them all-the-freakin-time.

commentThread.commentText: 47 and I just went back to working at a print shop after years of doing freelance. Nice to be back in the place I started again. Change can be good.

replies.commentText: Hey Corey - that's awesome. Print isn't dead baby!
@Philip VanDusen I am actually shocked at just how busy we are. Really nice to be busy from open to close every single day.

commentThread.commentText: A major factor may be money. For the price of an older, senior professional, the agency may be able to get 2 fresh and young hopefuls who will be more malleable.

replies.commentText: Yes, that's true. But they do it at the expense of any older creatives. Which is sadly short sighted. But instead of trying to change the world and that reality - my goal is to help people prepare for it. It has the habit of sneaking up on you...;-)

​@Philip VanDusen A great post - it's even prompted me to post - I whole heartedly agree about creating your own brand but I do feel that it starts and exists first in the real world, it's going to be based on who you are. Any digital manifest version of your brand will be a representation of who you are as a person, but digital. I can attest to this insomuch as I have made use of my own network and relationships to enable my own work and indeed career. Essentially working with friends does rule, but, you need to be emotionally mature enough to make sure it does work. Thus being an older designer can save the day.

@Beerhunter68 Beer, you're very right. I have "traded" on my successful 25 year in the agency and corporate world - establishing professional credibility by virtue of the clients and projects I have worked on as well as the huge departments and budgets I have run over the years. Not to mention the massive network of clients and partners I have amassed. All that made what I am doing now possible. But how early the age-discrimination came shocked me - and the more I looked at it across people I knew in the industry the more disturbing it became...Also, how unprepared I was to make the transition to an independent position - is why I'm always ringing the bell of personal branding to whoever will listen.

commentThread.commentText: Philip, are there any websites/blogs you recommend reading daily/weekly to keep up with the industry and trends, especially for a 45 yo creative director who wants to stay up to date?

replies.commentText: Here's a few I look at: https://designtaxi.com, https://www.stylus.com/, https://www.marketingweek.com/focus/design-branding/, https://www.trendhunter.com/, https://www.fastcompany.com/co-design

commentThread.commentText: Just some observations... a) Wisdom is seen as relative b) Culture is relative c) Wisdom to know who fits in their culture is relative d) Stereotypes are relative e) Energy to force a fit in vs a Quick fit f) Success views are relative g) Quick success vs long term success is relative h) Talent is relative i) etc is relative lol It seems anyone can fit anywhere given enough time, effort, acceptance, skill level etc. A theatrical example may be the Google movie (The Internship) with the older gent forcing his fit into the younger culture as an "older Google employee. As always generally speaking younger folks like to be around younger folks for "perceived" common denominators such as energy levels, political views, religious views, us vs them thought processes, definition of wisdom etc. The paradigms go on forever but like you suggest it's sometimes more wise to move on...amen. Love your videos and demeanor very much!

replies.commentText: Hey James, Very well articulated. Thanks for watching and taking the time to comment. I appreciate your sharing your POV. Basically "birds of a feather flock together" to feel understood and safe. But it is in forcing opposites or opposing "categories" ( age groups) together that innovative thinking and transformative ideas germinate. That's just IMHO. - Glad you are liking my channel - I'd stoked to have you here. I like people who truly engage.

commentThread.commentText: Excellent piece! I work in IT and work specifically in communications (web design, graphic design and content creation). I started in my 20s and am now 45, but because I work in the public service, I've continued to consult externally over the years since it's the only way to learn new skills and remain current. In my case, I got sidelined for any advancement but the work keeps coming. Senior leadership rave about summer students coming in to work in my unit, not because their work is great, but because they're young. There's this belief that everything they put out is "gonna be amazing!" Meanwhile, due to their youth they haven't fully developed the skills to do the job as well. Not saying they're bad, but years of experience (along with constant learning and growth) means as an older creative, my work is usually not only better, but delivered with a faster turn around. Add to that not all of them are open to suggestions on how to do things, because they already believe they're better than me just by being younger. The sidelining is like an Atlas Shrugged moment, where I'm expected do my job and pick up their slack, but am never recognized for how much that truly involves. If they do, it's usually begrudgingly. For the most part they act like they're entitled to all this experience and we're supposed to act like we don't know how good we are. It's not just the workplace either, but academic institutions as well. Back in my 20s you couldn't get a university degree in creative design, but I loved it so I'm self-taught. Today, one of our best universities for such programs won't offer it part-time. Full-time only, means people like us with years of practical experience but lacking that piece of paper, can't get in unless we quit our day jobs. Not one image on their website of all the happy students in that program, look a day over 22...it speaks volumes. Freelancing keeps me going at least. It's my "Who is John Galt?" stance to the day job...save the real creativity for myself. LOL! So until my eyes go or arthritis kicks in, they won't age me out. ^_^

replies.commentText: Andeen, AWESOME story. Thanks for sharing all that detail. I have to say (and I was as guilty of this as any other) Hubris is the curse of youth. They think they know everything. That will never change. What I hope does change, and I see it everyday in the comments and participation of the younger designers on this channel and in my community, is that younger designers seem to be getting better at trying to glean the experience of those who have gone before to help them grow and prosper in their careers. That's my goal here - and those who want to take advantage of it, can.

commentThread.commentText: Ive always thought the industry is very ageist.. ive experienced it soo many times

replies.commentText: Sadly, blatantly so. Fashion is even worse.

Philip VanDusen Philip VanDusen Haha that bell have been turned on since the first video that I watched from you. "Where's the YOU in your brand." I was a silent viewer/lurker before. But your content are just so explosively great and helpful and so I can't help but comment. ❤

commentThread.commentText: Recently, you highlighted a negative trend of using type that is too small. I feel this is because younger graphic designers are not always taught the basic principles of typography and readability. They have little access to this knowledge when the older, more experienced designers have been excluded from the workplace and from teaching in universities and colleges. I used to lecture design students on typographical rules for publishing, but I know that I was in a minority.

replies.commentText: Sonia, Design focusing on the Boomer and older generations will become more of a priority - that cohort has 4x the disposable income of Millennials and Gen X.

commentThread.commentText: Ageism is terrible and it's getting worse, in every field/industry but particularly those in the creative/design areas. Employers and agencies seem to think that those above 30 (35 best case scenario) have nothing to contribute. Some of the best designers and creative minds I know are well into their 40s or even older. Sometimes I think it's just an excuse to pay the employees less as a young person might be willing to accept a lower pay in order to get the gig or because they need less money to get by. One time, at an agency I worked at, we got an incredible portfolio and resume, we called the person in for an interview/meeting and when he got to the offices he was an older guy, possibly in his late 40s early 50s, the look on the faces of some of my colleagues was such a let down. It was like his age had already disqualified him and some didn't pay attention to what he had do said during the meeting, that was so rude and I even had an argument with some of them because of that. Of course, they didn't hire him and soon afterwords I started looking for another place to work, I just didn't feel that was the place for me anymore. I couldn't believe they were so elitist and snobs when it came t o age when all that mattered was his incredible work, skills, and abilities.

replies.commentText: Tony, Thanks for the great comment and the moving story. I have seen that happen as well. And sadly when I was younger, I probably did it myself I am now ashamed to say. I'm going to use your comment in a book I am writing with your permission, would you be open to sharing your full name so I can attribute it to you? If you cant do it here, email me through my website. Thanks! You rock BTW.

commentThread.commentText: Jobs come and go but your personal brand is forever. I enjoy your message. Thanks for sharing. ⭐️

replies.commentText: Well put Ali!

commentThread.commentText: Here I am.

replies.commentText: Danny - you and me both brother.

commentThread.commentText: Thank you for this message.  I'm over forty and pursuing a creative career.  Pretty nervous about it. However, I appreciate the challenge it presents and it's nice to see that it's on the minds of others.

replies.commentText: Eaton - as the Baby Boomer retire - or are retired involuntarily - it is a very hot topic and a critical one to bring into the conversation in our profession.

commentThread.commentText: for me it is great again to develop a product a while from scratch alone without the need of many specialists.

replies.commentText: Cool.

commentThread.commentText: isn‘t it a missing knowledge in modern technologies or tools? to keep up to date is a permanent learning curve

replies.commentText: Ritz - in the industry that doesn't matter a bit. Even of you are up to date - there is a perception you are not or are out of touch. You're also more expensive than younger folks.

commentThread.commentText: i‘m 61 and change since a year from project management consulting back to software development for my own products

replies.commentText: Ritz - good you are owning your own thing!

commentThread.commentText: I'm really enjoying your content. I'm 50 and just getting into UX / UI Design as a student. I've experienced ageism in my last career (Account Executive/sales), so I'm familiar. I'm nervous about this topic, but (finally) excited about what I'm doing.

replies.commentText: Heather- awesome that you are moving into creative. I can't count how many account people I've worked with who thought they were designers already. LOL (I'm sure you get the joke - --delivered good-naturedly of course!)

commentThread.commentText: Thank you for addressing this subject. I'm a web designer in my fifties and this is something that has been on my mind quite a bit.

replies.commentText: John, heed my advice. Build your own presence outside your job. Website, content, network, conferences, mastermind, mailing list. When the hammer falls...and I dare say it will, you'll be more ready.
Thank you, Philip. I'm hoping over the next few years that I can reach that point. I'm doing my best to implement all these things.
@Philip VanDusen This is exactly what I've been doing. Building my runway in the background and when the gravy train ends, I'll be able to transition smoothly.

commentThread.commentText:
Gosh, I just think about how I was in my twenties vs. how I am in my forties and there is a world of difference in how much of an asset I am now. Back then, like most young people, I was a lot more interested in my social life than my career. I was not reliable like I am now. I also did not have the discipline to keep a steady schedule or interact professionally when clients get aggravating. It seems like it's even worse if you're female, they assume you don't have time because of your kids (even if you don't have kids!) Strange world we live in.

I recently moved away from Silicon Valley and can confirm, the people who work at Facebook all appear to be about 25.

replies.commentText: Great story Kate - thanks for sharing your POV. All the points you made are so true - especially the client/conflict/emotional maturity thing.

commentThread.commentText: I love this. The past year, I've updated my website, created new work and plan to do more (replacing a lot that is up there) and continue to grow. I work very hard, spend my vacation time learning new skills, etc. It is SO important for older creatives.

replies.commentText: You're walkin the walk Kat.

commentThread.commentText:
On the day Tiger wins the Masters at 43, here's this video. 

Those oldies still have something to offer.

replies.commentText: ABC, damn straight.

commentThread.commentText:
Again, a big thanks! I totally relate to this speech. 'Shelf life' i like this! You can never prepare to be put aside from what you consider a passion more
than a job! Keep up your great work Phil.

replies.commentText: Alain, it all comes down to just changing the "delivery system" instead of an agency or company getting you the work and holding you in it's arms, you have to make your own way and develop your own brand. It's the reality. Which is why I'm always harping on about it.

commentThread.commentText: Thanks for sharing this, I've been struggling to move up in the industry for a few years and now in my mid 30s I feel like I'm starting making some traction - good to know it's not too late.

replies.commentText: Ryan, dude, I didn't even get my first job in design until I was 33. You are in your prime! Dig in!

commentThread.commentText: I was a freelancer from 25-40 years and just got hired by an ad agency as a 3D Lead Artist. Maybe it's due to the B2B typical lack of fuzziness or the fact that the agency will be 50 years in business and still owner operated (second generation), but I saw designers retire in their mid 60s. That's in northern Germany. I was always very much on the edge about aging in the industry, here I feel like I can let my guard down a  bit. Not too much though. ;) But great input, as always!

replies.commentText: Schlomo - the EU might be better at it. But here in the US, age is less valued as a rule in the creative fields.

commentThread.commentText: Great insight, you're absolutely correct. I was sidelined for many years and it affected me professionally. Now I'm virtually dead in the water struggling to get back in the game.

replies.commentText: DD, you can do it. Something will break loose or you'll have to go it alone and drum up work yourself through networking. Older creatives unfortunately have to forge their own paths after a time.

@Philip VanDusen Thank you for the encouragement. 
Correct again,  I can already see that this thing won't be playing out the way it did when I was much younger and used to be able to land a job with ease.

commentThread.commentText: Space X is a CGI producing company. Unfortunately there's reality replaced by the fantasy and the creatives by overrated en overpaid youngsters.

replies.commentText: Hey Duster! Thanks so much for checking out my video! I appreciate you taking the time to leave a comment. Keep tuning in!

commentThread.commentText: Genius is Genius is Genius. Flourish baby! FLOURISH!

replies.commentText: You rock Kira!

commentThread.commentText: Great advice and thank you!

replies.commentText: Thanks Tam!

commentThread.commentText: I'm wondering if its even something brought up during the interview. I ended up in this group of people unfortunately due to life circumstances, but I haven't given up my strive or creative arts. I think I'm on the final stretch, and this year will probably be the year that makes or breaks me. I'm at 40 now, and I've learned a lot, and gained experience, but I've never worked in this field professionally. Should I stop, or go forward full force? I have two degrees in design, and some adobe certs. I feel as if I've put a lot of time before I just throw in the towel due to this age stereotype.

replies.commentText: Official Kon, Have you tried being placed my creative temp agencies like Creative Circle or 24/7? Give them a try if you need help breaking in.

Thanks Philip, I'm currently considering that. I've been looking into them and The Creative Group here in Seattle. Also, I think for a big time its mostly been my fault not having my own website to view my portfolio, and relying on Behance. But, I've also just finished my MFA less than a couple of years ago so it hasn't been that long. Either way I'm going to keep at it. I will try your advice, and I'll keep watching your vids for pointers to get my foot finally in the door! @Philip VanDusen

commentThread.commentText: I imagine that there exists a power-house pool of highly valuable aged out talent that, should it choose to, could coalesce and rise as a substantial competitor to younger firms. Tech isn't an Olympic event where you can tear a muscle - it's a tool. Adopting it and learning it isn't like taking up title fighting at 40. I think that some of the cuts come down to higher levels of pay at a certain level - not just age. Young can also mean cheap to a degree. My industry is a lot less design than image making - illustration and art - but I started out as a designer. Another great video - much appreciated! Solidly in your corner!

replies.commentText: Matt, you hit the nail on the head with the "older means more expensive" and that is a big thing to companies. Also older workers make more use of benefits, healthcare in particular, which sends their rates up for carrying plans.

In agreement from experience. I witnessed this agism and lower salaries at one of the largest footwear companies in the world. The design org. fractionated design roles into more specialized roles that had very little creative latitude while creating a heavy design calendar with various gates and dates. They started hiring designers for those roles directly from college (usually design director Alumni colleges) with no previous footwear industry experience. These designers never knew they lost major design perks like, Design show travel, market research travel, event and product launch opportunities, and worst in my opinion (especially for a consumer products company) they were no longer invited or involved with brand athletes and focus groups for product design. 
This also created a very cliquish atmosphere on campus within design between new vs. experienced designers. 
Ultimately, It lead to an exodus of experienced designers leaving for better roles at other companies. It's why under armor was able to thrive when they began and it also fueled the competitor companies into making a comeback.

@l. p. Thanks for that story. I witnessed similar things in the fashion industry. These things go in cycles I've found. They "dumb-down" the creative department and then product design starts to suffer - then they amp it back up. Then they go totally out-of-house (out of house is always better right? LOL) Then they rebuild in-house and drop their FL's and agencies. It's like this dysfunctional dance.

commentThread.commentText: I got my MFA (in illustration at age 58!) so I could teach in my later creative life and have come up against the same problems! Lots of people in higher education, specially in tech and the creative professions, are still hesitant to hire someone older.

replies.commentText: I got my MFA in Painting to teach when I was 26 and teaching work was impossible to find. I looked for 4 years - eventually landing a gig in France for 9 months. I did it, and came back $3000 in debt. That's when I started my own company and eventually became a CD in the fashion industry. Good luck with your search - I wish you the very best!
Hire yourself! Do good work and shout about it! Age is just a number!!!! (unless, of course, you're like a-hundred-and-eight...)

@Philip VanDusen Thank You! I worked in cycling apparel for years and loved it.  I did surface design and experienced a ceiling when it came to promotions - I was suddenly a creative director who did no creating! I liked the industry even with its cut-throat zeitgeist.

Most CD's do no actual creating - hands-on anyway. Lots of designers think they want to be a CD until they find out what the job actually entails. They just want the extra money - and you can't blame them for that.

commentThread.commentText: I love it when you pop onto my screen!!! And as I head quickly to 60, this post was a bit of a wake up call. (And look out, folks, I'm doing the most creative work of my entire career! Shelf-life Shmelf-life! I am relevant, I am relevant...)

replies.commentText: You and me both brother. FYI, I have a brand•muse interview being posted next week with Steve Dotto of DottoTech and he discusses this topic in that show. be sure to keep your eye out for that one. Also he has a new podcast called "Grey Matters with Steve Dotto" you might like.
